answers.answer: Not yet, but will not surprise me if they do.  They are regulating what thyroid panels that they will pay for and how often.  That is why so many Doctors test just TSH.          Just sayin'     -sass-

I haven't been personally, but I have a friend who has been denied insurance, partially because of thyroid.  He has Graves Disease and had his thyroid removed many years ago. He also has type II diabetes and high blood pressure, both controlled with medication, but definitely contributing factors; he's been denied insurance by several companies, and thyroid has been listed as partial reason for denial.I'm planning to retire later this year, and most likely will run into the same issues.  I do not have diabetes (at this time), however, I've been on med for high blood pressure for many years, and of course, my Hashi/hypo status, along with pernicious anemia...... should be good for a few denials.

Hey LM:No denial of coverage, but with change to Medicare Anthem Blue Cross Freedom Blue from Health Net, Cytomel went from costing $35 to costing $85. Nightmare. The only other company that even had it on their formulary was Aetna, and the cost was the same. There is no price break for ordering it from mail order 3 months at a time, whereas before, I got 3 months worth for the price of 2 months. The pressure to change to generic medication is economically intense, and if you try to get generic medication for a lesser price through Walgreen's or CVS programs, they will not assure you that it will be from the same manufacturer every time for consistency of potency.

I thought with the passage of Obamacare that denial of benefits for pre-existing conditions was not allowed from any insurer. Isn't that true?I do know that Armour Thyroid (what I am currently taking) is pretty inexpensive even without insurance.

Shelley - you're right, Obamacare is supposed to eliminate denial of benefits; however, I don't believe that portion of the law goes into effect until, something like 2014.  Lots of time for the insurance companies to get the prices up so high we can't afford them; or possibly find loopholes in the law that will enable them deny anyway.  .

Yep , its play time till 2014.If there denying thyroid patients, then they must be denying around 25% of the public. I would guess around 25% has more (worse) health issues than thyroid. Rule of thumb, if they dont ask,..........then dont tell.Ive been paying for dessicated out of pocket for a couple years without ins Rx , its relatively inexpensive, but they dont like it. Go figure.And ins has dropped many Rx meds this year for other conditions from what I have heard.

I have had health insurance for the last 21yrs. I had a TT so I am clincially hypo. I have had to change health insurances at least four times since the TT (17yrs ago), but NOT once was I ever denied, nor did I have to pay higher premiums. Some forms asked about medical history & I listed it, but no problems stemmed from it. Now I am only on my husband's insurance as opposed to mine offered here at work.
Many never have been denied (most), but things are changing that we need to watch out for.

"Don't ask, don't tell" was repealed........... be prepared to cough up the info........ LOLI only know my friend has been denied coverage by several companies and one of the reasons listed was thyroid, but again, he also has Type II diabetes and high blood pressure.

What info?  We forget easily. LOLI think this mostly applies to individual insurance - they are most likely to look at everything.Group coverage seems to have way less questions. I have never seen thyroid on the 'check off box' list.There is also the law that states you may be denied new coverage if you did not previously have any. Very high deductible is still included as 'coverage' , so people at need this as a minimum.

Info?? did I ask for info??  golly, guess the brain fog took over again.......  LOLYou are right, that most of the denials are for "personal" or "individual" insurance.  My friend was self-employed.I think the thing with group coverage is that they have to cover you, no matter what, unless you have been without insurance for a period of time, and have certain medical issues. Again different states may have different laws.

I believe its called the Affordable Health Care Act.  January 1, 2014, is when it should be in effect by.  We can't afford our healthcare premiums and my husband will not be able to get insurance because he was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes.  My son who is 19 was diagnosed with Hashimoto's, thyroid condition, and I know he won't be able to be covered.  I'm at my wit's end what to do.  Even when the new law for pre-existing conditions becomes effective, can you imagine how much they're going to charge us for it?

question: Health insurance is a hot topic as the prices soar and they cover less and less, no shocker there. Changes are happening at a very fast pace all of a sudden, and, of course we get the short end of the stick.Some basic meds are not even covered at all by some insurance companies now.I have not personally seen any insurance company list hypothyroid on there current conditions list or denial of coverage list, but apparently this can be the case. There are different state laws that pertain to this as well.So anyone had coverage denied or pay even higher premiums based on their thyroid disorder recently?
title: Been denied health Insurance because of a thyroid disorder lately?
